results.abstract: China challenges US and Russian dominance of space with plans to launch manned capsule into orbit around Earth by end of year, speeding up project meant to showcase Chinese technology (S)

headline.main: Chinese Space Effort Challenges Russia and U.S.

results.snippet: Even as the United States and Russia grow cautious about the cost of exploring other worlds, China is taking the first steps to challenging their longtime pre-eminence in space.     Beijing plans to launch a manned capsule into orbit around Earth by...
results.lead_paragraph: Even as the United States and Russia grow cautious about the cost of exploring other worlds, China is taking the first steps to challenging their longtime pre-eminence in space. Beijing plans to launch a manned capsule into orbit around Earth by the end of the year, speeding up an effort intended to showcase its growing technological abilities and to take advantage of the scientific, military and commercial potential of space.

results.lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com. MUSIC BICKFORD THEATER Terry Blaine, jazz vocalist. Monday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $13. Morris Museum, 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 971-3706. COMMUNITY THEATER New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, featuring Leila Josefowicz, violinist. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $17 to $54. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 539-8008.

results.abstract: Robot Chinese space capsule returns safely to Earth, laying groundwork for China to try to send astronaut into space this year; successful piloted flight would make China only third country able to send its own astronuats into space (S)

headline.main: China Space Capsule Paves Way for Flight By an Astronaut

results.snippet: A robot Chinese space capsule returned safely to Earth today, state media said, laying the groundwork for China to try to send an astronaut into space this year.    A successful piloted flight would make China only the third country, after Russia and...
results.lead_paragraph: A robot Chinese space capsule returned safely to Earth today, state media said, laying the groundwork for China to try to send an astronaut into space this year. A successful piloted flight would make China only the third country, after Russia and the United States, able to send its own astronauts into space.

results.abstract: Armed man commandeers small plane in Frankfurt, Ger, and threatens to crash it into headquarters of European Central Bank before authorities talk him into landing safely at airport; police arrest man, whom they decline to identify except to say he is 31-year-old German suffering from 'complete loss of reality'; rogue pilot causes havoc, shutting down airport and paralyzing city; suspect took two-seat plane from private flying club in Babenhausen, southeast of Frankfurt, after threatening pilot with gun and forcing him off plane; photos; map (M)

headline.main: German Threatens to Crash Glider Into Frankfurt Bank

results.snippet: In what appeared to be a bizarre bid for attention, an armed man commandeered a small plane here today and threatened to crash it into the headquarters of the European Central Bank, before the authorities talked him into landing safely at Frankfurt...
results.lead_paragraph: In what appeared to be a bizarre bid for attention, an armed man commandeered a small plane here today and threatened to crash it into the headquarters of the European Central Bank, before the authorities talked him into landing safely at Frankfurt airport. The police arrested the man, whom they declined to identify, shortly after the plane touched down. The president of the Frankfurt police, Harald Weiss-Bollandt, said at a news briefing that the man, who is 31 and German, was ''suffering from a complete loss of reality.''

results.abstract: Favorite non-mainstream CD's of 2002 are named by New York Times critics, including Neil Strauss, Jon Pareles, Ben Ratliff and Kelefa Sanneh; photos (L)

headline.main: The Pop Life; Tributaries to the Musical Mainstream

results.snippet: Last year record labels released about 27,000 CD titles in the United States. Though that it is a hefty number, it is actually low for the business, which released nearly 39,000 titles just a few years ago. Considering that only several hundred of...
results.lead_paragraph: Last year record labels released about 27,000 CD titles in the United States. Though that it is a hefty number, it is actually low for the business, which released nearly 39,000 titles just a few years ago. Considering that only several hundred of those CD's even make the Top 40, that leaves thousands upon thousands of CD's that few people ever hear. Thus, every year, the pop music critics at The New York Times compile a list of the CD's that almost got away the previous year. The choices here include CD's on small independent labels; groups whose music has never been released domestically; acts who work in genres that are far too experimental or avant-garde for mainstream radio; older legends making a comeback; and younger musicians with the potential to become legends.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Columbia, protected by layers of tight security, is poised to take off this week on scientifically challenging mission that is also one of most politically delicate in space program's history; on Jan 16, Columbia is to lift off on 16-day research flight crammed with more than 90 experiments and investigation that will mean round-the-clock duties for its seven-member crew, which includes Col Ilan Ramon, first Israeli astronaut; photo; drawing (M)

headline.main: Amid Tight Security, Crew of Shuttle Focuses on Science

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia, protected by layers of tight security, is poised to take off this week on a scientifically challenging mission that is also one of the most politically delicate in the space program's history.    On Thursday, Columbia is...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia, protected by layers of tight security, is poised to take off this week on a scientifically challenging mission that is also one of the most politically delicate in the space program's history. On Thursday, Columbia is to lift off on a 16-day research flight crammed with more than 90 experiments and investigations that will mean round-the-clock duties for its seven-member crew, which includes the first Israeli astronaut.

results.abstract: NASA clears space shuttle Columbia for launching after determining that oxygen line crack in another shuttle is not threat to Columbia (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: NASA Sets Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: NASA cleared the space shuttle Columbia for launching today on a 16-day science mission with a crew that includes the first Israeli astronaut. NASA managers issued the order after determining that an oxygen line crack in another shuttle was not a...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA cleared the space shuttle Columbia for launching today on a 16-day science mission with a crew that includes the first Israeli astronaut. NASA managers issued the order after determining that an oxygen line crack in another shuttle was not a threat to Columbia. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

results.abstract: Selena Roberts Sports of The Times column compares treatment of amateur figure skaters like Michelle Kwan, who is often allowed to earn money from ice shows, to that of high school basketball players like LeBron James, who is being investigated for recent acquisition of new car; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; They're All Amateurs. Go Figure.

results.snippet: THERE is a teenage phenom with the vertical leap of an astronaut on a moonscape who possesses the flair of a Vegas act and enough potential to rock a sport. LeBron James? No, Sasha Cohen.     There is a high school senior with a life story that has...
results.lead_paragraph: THERE is a teenage phenom with the vertical leap of an astronaut on a moonscape who possesses the flair of a Vegas act and enough potential to rock a sport. LeBron James? No, Sasha Cohen. There is a high school senior with a life story that has unfolded on TV who doesn't have an agent, but has companies panting like groupies wanting to turn the hot teenager's head. This could be King James, but it's Sarah Hughes.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Columbia takes off on 16-day research mission amid high security with crew that includes Ilan Ramon, first astronaut from Israel; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Lifts Off With an Israeli Astronaut

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia roared off into a picture-perfect sky today to begin a 16-day research mission with a crew that includes the first astronaut from Israel.    The shuttle, with a crew of five men and two women, lifted off on time without...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia roared off into a picture-perfect sky today to begin a 16-day research mission with a crew that includes the first astronaut from Israel. The shuttle, with a crew of five men and two women, lifted off on time without incident at 10:39 a.m. and quickly climbed on a column of smoke through a bright sky punctuated by puffs of white clouds.

headline.main: Why We Kindle the Dreams of the Young

results.snippet: MY son is planning to be Steven Spielberg when he grows up. To this end, he has read every Spielberg biography he can find, has added his own English essays to the existing literature and has a framed poster from ''Saving Private Ryan'' hanging on...
results.lead_paragraph: MY son is planning to be Steven Spielberg when he grows up. To this end, he has read every Spielberg biography he can find, has added his own English essays to the existing literature and has a framed poster from ''Saving Private Ryan'' hanging on his bedroom wall. (Yes, we let an 11-year-old see an R-rated movie; please don't send angry e-mail messages. It's tough to argue with a child who wants to increase his knowledge of camera angles and special effects, and who has already read the screenplay.) Because technology moves as fast as it does, Evan even has a head start on The Man himself. When Mr. Spielberg was 11, all he had to work with was a Super 8 camera; his editing method was to film in sequence. Evan is equipped with a borrowed Canon ZR50MC digital camcorder and the iMovie 2 film-editing software that came with our iMac computer.

results.abstract: Astronaut Hall of Fame in Titusville, Fla, reopens to visitors after being acquired by Kennedy Space Center (M)

headline.main: Astronaut Hall of Fame Reopens in Florida

results.snippet: Visitors can use training simulators to land a Space Shuttle and take a virtual moon walk at the Astronaut Hall of Fame, the newest attraction at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The Hall of Fame, in Titusville, six miles west of the center's...
results.lead_paragraph: Visitors can use training simulators to land a Space Shuttle and take a virtual moon walk at the Astronaut Hall of Fame, the newest attraction at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The Hall of Fame, in Titusville, six miles west of the center's visitor complex, reopened in December after the space center acquired it. The hall, previously run by the U.S. Space Camp Foundation, displays memorabilia and tributes to participants of the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs. The exhibit hall has a collection of spacecraft, including a Mercury Sigma 7 capsule, a Gemini training capsule and the Apollo 14 command module.

results.abstract: Robotic milking systems, popular for years in Europe, are gaining adherents in US and Canada; computer admits cows to milking area where laser-guided robotic arm takes over; photos illustrate how system works (M)

headline.main: The Flexible Farmer Lets the Robot Do the Milking

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: LASER (LIGHT AMPLIFICATION BY STIMULATED EMISSION OF RADIATION)

results.snippet: FOR most of the last 20 years, the milking at the Cloverdale Farm was an unwelcome ritual for both the cows and the people. Every morning the owner, Wayne Edwards, and an assistant would wake up at 5:30 and spend the next two hours milking. Then...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR most of the last 20 years, the milking at the Cloverdale Farm was an unwelcome ritual for both the cows and the people. Every morning the owner, Wayne Edwards, and an assistant would wake up at 5:30 and spend the next two hours milking. Then every afternoon at 4 the process began again, this time lasting about three hours with cleanup. ''You had to be there, there was no way around it,'' Mr. Edwards said. The cows were not happy with the rigid schedule either, he said.

results.abstract: Editorial on upcoming faceoff between chess master Garry Kasparov and computer program called Deep Junior; says, whoever wins this match, days when humans can compete with computers would seem to be numbered
results.snippet: Garry Kasparov, perhaps the greatest chess player in human history, will compete against a computer program in a six-game match at the New York Athletic Club starting Sunday in an effort to rebound from his stunning loss in 1997 to I.B.M.'s Deep Blue...
results.lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, perhaps the greatest chess player in human history, will compete against a computer program in a six-game match at the New York Athletic Club starting Sunday in an effort to rebound from his stunning loss in 1997 to I.B.M.'s Deep Blue computer. Deep Blue not only beat Mr. Kasparov on the chessboard in that go-round; it also wounded him psychologically, provoked him into blunders and reduced him to tantrums afterward. Since then, Deep Blue has retired from chess while Mr. Kasparov has been dethroned as world champion (human division) by his protégé, Vladimir Kramnik, who upset him in head-to-head competition in 2000. Mr. Kramnik, known as ''Mr. Iceberg'' for his coolness under pressure, took his own turn last year against a German-Dutch computer program known as Deep Fritz, which beat out other top computer programs to qualify. Mr. Kramnik, who was helped by rules designed to circumscribe the computer's awesome powers, jumped to a quick lead in the series but then began to melt. He was lucky to escape with a tie.

results.abstract: Researchers from Tel Aviv University report success of Israeli experiment aboard space shuttle Columbia; Dr Joachim Joseph explains study of effects of dust storms on weather and recording of electrical phenomena atop storm clouds; flight is carrying air force pilot Col Ilan Ramon, first Israeli astronaut (S)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Crew Completes Israeli Dust and Cloud Studies

results.snippet: The Israeli experiment aboard the space shuttle Columbia has accomplished its goals of studying the effects of dust storms on weather and recording electrical phenomena atop storm clouds, scientists said today.    Researchers from Tel Aviv University...
results.lead_paragraph: The Israeli experiment aboard the space shuttle Columbia has accomplished its goals of studying the effects of dust storms on weather and recording electrical phenomena atop storm clouds, scientists said today. Researchers from Tel Aviv University said their Mediterranean Israeli Dust Experiment had gathered solid information on the plumes of dust and other aerosol particles blown from deserts by storms before being carried worldwide by high winds. The particles affect rain production in clouds, deposit minerals in the ocean and scatter sunlight that affects global warming, the scientists said.
